chapter.title: Operating &ceph; Services
chapter.para: You can operate &ceph; services either using &systemd;, or using &deepsea;.

sect1.title: Operating &ceph; Services using &systemd;
sect1.para: Use the systemctl command to operate all &ceph; related services. The operation takes place on the node you are currently logged in to. You need to have &rootuser; privileges to be able to operate on &ceph; services.

sect2.title: Starting, Stopping, and Restarting Services using Targets
sect2.para: To simplify starting, stopping, and restarting all the services of a particular type (for example all &ceph; services, or all MONs, or all OSDs) on a node, &ceph; provides the following &systemd; unit files:
sect2.screen: &prompt.root; ls /usr/lib/systemd/system/ceph*.target ceph.target ceph-osd.target ceph-mon.target ceph-mgr.target ceph-mds.target ceph-radosgw.target ceph-rbd-mirror.target
sect2.para: To start/stop/restart all &ceph; services on the node, run:
sect2.screen: &prompt.root;systemctl stop ceph.target &prompt.root;systemctl start ceph.target &prompt.root;systemctl restart ceph.target
sect2.para: To start/stop/restart all OSDs on the node, run:
sect2.screen: &prompt.root;systemctl stop ceph-osd.target &prompt.root;systemctl start ceph-osd.target &prompt.root;systemctl restart ceph-osd.target
sect2.para: Commands for the other targets are analogous.

listitem.para: For &deepsea; prior to version 0.8.4, the &mds;, &igw;, &ogw;, and &ganesha; services restart in parallel.

For &deepsea; 0.8.4 and newer, all roles you have configured restart in the following order: &mon;, &mgr;, &osd;, &mds;, &rgw;, &igw;, &ganesha;. To keep the downtime low and to find potential issues as early as possible, nodes are restarted sequentially. For example, only one monitoring node is restarted at a time.

sect2.para: The command waits for the cluster to recover if the cluster is in a degraded, unhealthy state.
